description.narrative: In late 2017, the foundation for the strategy of the Netherlands embassy on wind energy in Vietnam was laid: a baseline study was implemented to gain knowledge on the (potential) wind energy sector in Vietnam. After that, many more activities followed among others visits of the Ministry of Industry and Trade (MoIT) to the Netherlands as well as mission from the Netherlands to Vietnam encompassing several institutes and companies. Late 2018 a more structured approach was chosen and elaborated in a roadmap Offshore Wind Development, with clear milestone and long-term vison. This roadmap is part of the multi-annual country strategy and find its way in economic workplans.However, one of the identified obstacles for a fast-developing offshore wind energy sector in Vietnam is the lack of suitable infrastructure. Constructions of large offshore wind farms and large turbine systems are feasible, but it requires a special port infrastructure that provides high-technical services for offshore construction and offshore O&M (a so-called “Energy Port”). Vietnam's seaport system includes 45 seaports. The development of the port system in Vietnam is planned with special attention on ensuring uninterrupted connection between ports & harbors for international and national traffic networks, goods distribution and logistics service. Some seaports have been invested with international stature scales such as Ba Ria - Vung Tau seaport and Hai Phong seaport. However, most of them do not yet meet the requirements for an energy port. This present project is aimed to identify the outline and requirements of harbor that can be used for onshore and offshore activities regards wind offshore. This includes logistics and management of inland infra structure. This will be based on experience in Western European countries with emphasis on Dutch experiences.
